title: How to Recycle Plaster of Paris

steps.title: Put the plaster mold into your oven or toaster oven.
steps.content: Put the plaster mold into your oven or toaster oven. Either one will work, as long as it gets hot enough. Place the mold on a baking sheet or tray, then put it in the oven. [2] X Research source The baking process removes all the water from the plaster so you can reuse it later on.

steps.title: Set your oven to 180 °C (356 °F).
steps.content: Set your oven to 180 °C (356 °F). At this temperature, the plaster will get hot enough for all the water to evaporate. This preps the plaster for recycling. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Bake the plaster for 2 hours.
steps.content: Bake the plaster for 2 hours. Leave the plaster in the oven and let it bake. After 2 hours, the plaster should be completely dried out. [4] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Check back on the oven periodically to make sure it’s still on and at the right temperature.

steps.title: Remove the plaster and let it cool.
steps.content: Remove the plaster and let it cool. Use oven mitts or a towel and pull the tray out of the oven. Let the plaster rest on your stovetop until it’s cool enough to handle. [5] X Research source If you keep thick work gloves on, you could probably handle the plaster while it’s still hot and start breaking it up right away. Just be careful not to let any touch your skin.

steps.title: Put on goggles to protect your eyes.
steps.content: Put on goggles to protect your eyes. Pieces of plaster could fly around while you’re breaking up the mold, so always be safe and put goggles on first. Ideally, use goggles that wrap around your eyes so you have protection all around. If you have asthma, then wearing a dust mask is a good idea too. There might be some powder particles that could make you cough.

steps.title: Break up the plaster mold into small pieces with a hammer.
steps.content: Break up the plaster mold into small pieces with a hammer. Put the mold in a durable metal or plastic tray, and rest it on a solid surface like a workbench. Hit the mold with a hammer to break it up into pieces. Continue hammering until the pieces are as small as possible. [6] X Research source If the plaster is tough to break up, you could also use a chisel to help. This is also good for breaking up smaller pieces.

steps.title: Pulverize the pieces into powder.
steps.content: Pulverize the pieces into powder. The plaster needs to be in powder form to reuse. Continue pounding the mold until the pieces are small. Then hit or grind the pieces with the flat top of a sledgehammer to reduce it into a powder. [7] X Research source You could also wrap the plaster in a towel or bag and crush it up with your hammer. This pulverizes it without getting powder everywhere.

steps.title: Pick out any dirt or debris from the plaster.
steps.content: Pick out any dirt or debris from the plaster. Check the powder for any debris like this. Pick it out so it doesn’t interfere with the plaster curing process. [8] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you don’t use the plaster again right away, keep it stored in a plastic bag or bucket so it doesn’t get dirty.

steps.title: Bake the powder in the oven again for another 2 hours.
steps.content: Bake the powder in the oven again for another 2 hours. All of the water has to be evaporated or the plaster won't re-form correctly. Pour all of the powder into an oven-safe tray or pan and set your oven back to 180 °C (356 °F). Put the pan into the oven and bake the plaster for another 2 hours to get rid of any remaining water. [9] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Re-form the plaster when you’re ready to make another mold.
steps.content: Re-form the plaster when you’re ready to make another mold. The process is the same as using the plaster for the first time. Mix together 1 part of cold water with 2 parts of plaster in a clean container. Stir the mixture until it reaches a jelly-like consistency and pour it into the mold. Remove the plaster after 1 hour and give the mold 3 days to fully cure. [10] X Research source Don’t mix more plaster than you can use in 7-12 minutes because it’ll start hardening.

steps.title: Repeat this process any time you want to recycle the mold.
steps.content: Repeat this process any time you want to recycle the mold. Studies show that you can dry, crush, and reuse plaster of Paris many times without any problems. Use this same method as often as you want to, as long as the plaster is curing and hardening properly. [11] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If the mold isn’t curing properly or seems too soft, then you probably need some new plaster.
